newsitem.title: KAZAKHSTAN: Tajikistan sees 600,000 T cotton harvest for 1997.
newsitem.headline: Tajikistan sees 600,000 T cotton harvest for 1997.

text.p: Tajikistan, ravaged by a four-year civil war, plans to harvest 600,000 tonnes of raw cotton this year, nearly double the 1996 harvest, a senior government official said on Tuesday.

"This figure will become a reality if we manage to provide our farms with enough fuel, mineral feritilisers and spare parts for machinery," Muso Barotov, the former Soviet republic's agriculture minister, told Reuters by telephone from the Tajik capital Dushanbe.

The impoverished Central Asian state, where cotton and an aluminium smelter are the main earners of hard currency, harvested only 312,000 tonnes of raw cotton last year, well short of the 500,000-tonne target.
In Soviet times, it harvested 850,000-900,000 tonnes of raw cotton a year.
Barotov said a total of 230,000 hectares -- 7,000 more than in 1996 -- would be sown with cotton this year.
But Radzhab Kadirov, an Agriculture Ministry department chief, said 40 percent of land in Tajikistan's southern Khatlon cotton belt had not been ploughed.
He said only 25,500 tonnes of cotton seed out of 29,000 tonnes needed were available for sowing and that financial difficulties meant there was no fertiliser for most fields.
The government of the cash-strapped republic has pinned its hopes on future contracts based on this year's cotton harvest.

"The state cotton company Khlopkoprom alone has received from its foreign partners a total of $50 million for future contracts, which will enable the purchase of more fuel and fertilisers," Barotov said.
The minister said the government was negotiating a loan for the cotton industry with Russia.
